statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Washington 99, American 82
article.story: SEATTLE (AP) -- The Washington Huskies thought they played poorly enough to lose. "We were fortunate we didn't experience a loss tonight," coach Lorenzo Romar said after the Huskies pulled ahead in the second half to beat American University 99-82 on Saturday night. "But we weren't very good. We're a better defensive team than we showed," Romar added following the Huskies' school-record 26th consecutive home victory. Washington is now tied with Gonzaga for the longest current home victory string in the nation. The Huskies (4-0) rallied after being tied at 41-41 by the Eagles (0-1) at the end of the first half. For the second straight game, the Huskies had to overcome themselves in the second half. On Tuesday, they overcame a 46-40 halftime deficit to beat Air Force 85-74 in the finals of the Black Coaches Association Classic in Seattle. "We can't continue that pattern," Romar said. Although he said it was too early in the season to worry about playing poorly in the first half, his players had concerns as well. "We played bad," senior forward Jamal Williams said. "We were lucky to squeak by with a win. We didn't play well." Senior forward Bobby Jones said he thought the Huskies were 30 to 40 points better than American. "With our talent, we should have gotten them out of their comfort zone," Jones said. The Huskies had five players in double figures, led by senior swingman Brandon Roy's 17 points, 15 in the second half. Freshman forward Jon Brockman added 16 points and six rebounds, Williams had 14 points and seven rebounds, Florida transfer Ryan Appleby contributed 14 points, including three 3-pointers, and Jones had 11 points before fouling out with 4:07 to go. Guard Andre Ingram led American with 24 points, 14 in the first half, while guard Arvydas Eitutavicius added 14 for the Eagles. American coach Jeff Jones said his team just ran out of steam against the Huskies. "Our kids battled for a while," Jones said. "We scrapped in the first half to hang in there with them. But we were mismatched physically. They just wore us down." Washington had a 43-36 rebounding advantage. Jones was particularly impressed with Brockman, a physical 6-foot-7, 245-pounder. "I saw him in high school," he said. "He's a tough kid. He's just relentless." Holding a 50-48 lead with 2:19 gone in the second half, Washington went on a 12-0 run that began with a 3-pointer and a 16-footer by Roy. He ended the run with a free throw with 14:22 to go to give the Huskies a 62-48 advantage. Washington jumped to a 7-0 lead in the game's first 53 seconds. But American came back to sink three 3-pointers to tie the score at 9 with 3:44 gone. The Eagles took their first lead at 26-25 on a 15-footer by Ingram with 10:26 left in the first half and were in front 40-36 after a pair of free throws by Ingram with 3:21 left. The Huskies tied the score at 41 on an offensive rebound tip-in by Williams with 1:04 remaining in the opening half. American, which is in the Patriot League, had a 16-12 record last season.
